item.title: Memory Systems and Paging
item.description: Types of memory Static vs Dynamic Static RAM (SRAM): Flip-flop used to store each bit. Expensive but fairly simple. Dynamic RAM (DRAM): Capacitor used to store each bit, charge leaks away so refresh circuitry needed - increases complexity. Otherwise, generally cheaper once you have the refresh circuitry, so more common. Chip types Type Read/Write Volatility Random Access Memory (RAM) Electrically, at byte level Volatile Read Only Memory (ROM) Read only - written by mask at manufacture Non-volatile Programmable ROM (PROM) Read only - write once, electrically Non-volatile Erasable PROM (EPROM) Can erase whole chip with UV light, then rewrite Non-volatile Electrically Erasable PROM (EEPROM) Electrically erase whole chip, then rewrite Non-volatile Flash Memory Can erase each block and rewrite Non-volatile Advanced DRAM organisation Synchronous DRAM (SDRAM): Synchronously exchanges information with the processor on clock cycles.
